What are regex? - Strings that may include wildcards and special symbols. - Used to match (portions of) strings in complex queries. - In Python we can use the `re` library. ::: {.cell execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} import re ``` ::: ## Main `re` functions - `pattern` = regular expression - `string` = where to look for it Function | Looks for ---- | ------- `re.match(pattern, string)` | match at the beginning `re.search(pattern, string)` | first match anywhere `re.findall(pattern, string)` | all matches ::: footer [More about regex](https://docs.python.org/3/library/re.html#regular-expression-syntax) ::: ## Regex example I A sequence of non-special characters is taken literally. ::: {.cell execution_count=17} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.match('A', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=398} ``` ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=18} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.match('a', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.') ``` ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=19} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.search('a', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.')[0] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=400} ``` 'a' ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=20} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.findall('a', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=401} ``` ['a'] ``` ::: ::: ::: footer [More about regex](https://docs.python.org/3/library/re.html#regular-expression-syntax) ::: ## Wildcards The most important wildcard is the `.`, that represents **any character**. ::: {.cell execution_count=21} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.search('.', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=402} ``` ``` ::: ::: Two dots match a sequence of two characters; three dots a sequences of three characters... ::: {.cell execution_count=22} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.search('...', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=403} ``` ``` ::: ::: ::: footer [More about regex](https://docs.python.org/3/library/re.html#regular-expression-syntax) ::: ## Escaping If you want to capture a literal period, you need to escape it with `.` ::: {.cell execution_count=23} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.search('..\.', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=404} ``` ``` ::: ::: Other special characters we'll see can also be escaped with `\`. ::: footer [More about regex](https://docs.python.org/3/library/re.html#regular-expression-syntax) ::: ## Other useful symbols - `\w` = word character - `\s` = space character - `\d` = digit - `\b` = word boundary - `^` = beginning of a _line_ - `$` = end of a _line_ ::: footer [More about regex](https://docs.python.org/3/library/re.html#regular-expression-syntax) ::: ## Brackets You can match one of several options by including them in brackets. ::: {.cell execution_count=24} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.findall('[Aa]', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=405} ``` ['A', 'a'] ``` ::: ::: The options can be in a range; `[a-z]` indicates all lowercase letters; `[A-Z]` all uppercase letters, `[0-9]` all digits... ::: {.cell execution_count=25} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.search('san[a-z]', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.')[0] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=406} ``` 'sand' ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=26} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.search('[0-9]', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.')[0] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=407} ``` '3' ``` ::: ::: ::: footer [More about regex](https://docs.python.org/3/library/re.html#regular-expression-syntax) ::: ## Quantifiers To find a pattern of something repeated multiple times, you can ask that in several ways. The most common one is by attaching `*`, `+` or `?` to a character or group. (We'll see more about groups in a bit). ::: footer [More about regex](https://docs.python.org/3/library/re.html#regular-expression-syntax) ::: ## Asterisk An `*` asks for something that occurs **zero or more times**. ::: {.cell execution_count=27} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.search('sand*wich', 'A sanddddwich with 3 ingredients.')[0] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=408} ``` 'sanddddwich' ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=28} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.search('sand*wich', 'A sanwich with 3 ingredients.')[0] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=409} ``` 'sanwich' ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=29} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.search('sand*wich', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.')[0] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=410} ``` 'sandwich' ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=30} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.search('[0-9][a-z]* ingredients', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.')[0] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=411} ``` '3 ingredients' ``` ::: ::: ::: footer [More about regex](https://docs.python.org/3/library/re.html#regular-expression-syntax) ::: ## Plus A `+` asks for something that occurs **one or more times**. ::: {.cell execution_count=31} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.search('[0-9]+ ingredients', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.')[0] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=412} ``` '3 ingredients' ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=32} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.search('sandiche+', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.') # returns nothing ``` ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=33} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.findall('\w+', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=414} ``` ['A', 'sandwich', 'with', '3', 'ingredients'] ``` ::: ::: ::: footer [More about regex](https://docs.python.org/3/library/re.html#regular-expression-syntax) ::: ## Question mark A `?` asks for something that occurs **zero or one times**. ::: {.cell execution_count=34} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.search('[0-9]? ingredients', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.')[0] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=415} ``` '3 ingredients' ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=35} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.search('sandwiche?', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.')[0] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=416} ``` 'sandwich' ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=36} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.findall('s[a-z]?', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=417} ``` ['sa', 's'] ``` ::: ::: ::: footer [More about regex](https://docs.python.org/3/library/re.html#regular-expression-syntax) ::: ## Groups We can make groups by surrounding fragments of the regex in parentheses. - To apply a quantifier to the full group. ::: {.cell execution_count=37} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.search('([a-z]+ )+', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.')[0] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=418} ``` 'sandwich with ' ``` ::: ::: - To retrieve the groups ::: {.cell execution_count=38} ``` {.python .cell-code} re.match('(A ).+(\d+)', 'A sandwich with 3 ingredients.').groups() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=419} ``` ('A ', '3') ``` ::: ::: ::: footer [More about regex](https://docs.python.org/3/library/re.html#regular-expression-syntax) ::: ##
